prompt_text: You are a chatbot designed to help older adults (ages 65+) understand digital consent. Please explain, in simple 6th–7th grade reading-level English, what it means for a user to give consent to a chatbot service. Break the explanation into short sentences, provide bullet points, avoid technical jargon, and include a short summary at the end to reinforce memory. Your response must be easy to read for people with declining vision or mild cognitive load.
references: Xiao, Z. et al., 'Inform the Uninformed: Improving Online Informed Consent Reading with an AI-Powered Chatbot', 2023.
Frontiers in Digital Health, 'Applying a Digital Health Checklist and Readability Tools to Improve Informed Consent', 2021.

prompt_text: Explain to a senior user how they can review and accept or decline data-use terms in a chatbot interface designed with accessibility in mind. Describe the layout using large buttons, high-contrast text, and clear spacing. Write in a calm, reassuring tone and specify step-by-step what the user should click. Avoid all jargon. Your explanation should help users with visual limitations or slower interaction speed.
references: CMU GetGoing Project, 'An Understandable and Memorable Dialog System for Seniors', 2019.
Frontiers in Digital Health, 'Applying a Digital Health Checklist and Readability Tools to Improve Informed Consent', 2021.

prompt_text: Act as a consent assistant for older adults. Explain a step-by-step consent confirmation workflow designed specifically for seniors: (1) show the information, (2) summarize key risks, (3) ask for confirmation, (4) show a second confirmation screen, (5) provide an easy way to go back. Use very clear transitions such as 'First', 'Next', 'Then', and 'Finally'. Make sure all explanations use low cognitive load and avoid ambiguity.
references: Ethical Issues in Consenting Older Adults, NIH / PMC, 2019.
Xiao, Z. et al., 'Inform the Uninformed', 2023.

prompt_text: Explain consent terms to a senior user in a way that supports memory and comprehension. Provide repeated summaries, short key phrases, and optional reminders. Use a gentle tone. Highlight the most important parts using simple emphasis phrases such as 'This is important:' or 'Please remember:'. Make the content scannable and suitable for older adults who may forget details or require repeated clarification.
references: CMU GetGoing Project, 'Dialog System for Seniors', 2019.
Ethical Issues in Consenting Older Adults, NIH / PMC, 2019.

prompt_text: Explain to an older adult what their data rights are when using a chatbot service. Describe clearly how they can withdraw consent, delete their data, ask questions, or stop the service at any time. Avoid legal language. Use short bullet points and examples such as 'If you change your mind later…'. Provide reassurance that they can always revise or undo their decisions.
references: Empowering Users in Digital Privacy Management through Interactive LLM-Based Agents, 2024.
Privacy Attitudes and Concerns in Older Adults, Westin Typology Study, 2018.
